measured_by: average score on four comparative Likert items (–4 to +4) rating each focal group member vs. the group average
justification: “Each comparative question required the participants to judge the randomly selected group member… The Likert scale ranged from –4 (much less than the average member of this group)… NSSB is calculated as the average of their answers to the comparative questions.”

measured_by: average score on four negative-trait comparative Likert items (–4 to +4) for each group member vs. group average
justification: In Study 7 “…participants answered four comparative questions. Characteristics in this study were negative: ‘revolting,’ ‘yucky,’ ‘disgusting’ and ‘sickening.’ … bias magnitude was computed for each target,” indicating NSIB derived from these comparative ratings.

measured_by: single 5-point Likert item asking how similar or different the four group members are
justification: “Participants were also asked ‘To what extent are all group members perceived as similar or different from each other?’ using a 5-point Likert scale, ranging from 1 (‘very different’) to 5 (‘very similar’).”

measured_by: single 5-point Likert item ranging from ‘like it very much’ to ‘dislike it very much’
justification: “Participants were asked to judge to what extent they liked or disliked the group they created… rated using a 5-point Likert scale ranging from ‘like it very much’ to ‘dislike it very much.’”

measured_by: single 5-point Likert item ranging from ‘highly appraised as a good group’ to ‘highly appraised as a bad group’
justification: “…participants were asked… to what extent they estimated the group valence as a positive or negative group. Both questions were rated using a 5-point Likert scale… ranging from ‘highly appraised as a good group’ to ‘highly appraised as a bad group’.”
